urls.title: ‎Healthcare Unfiltered: Challenges and Bias against IMGs in America on Apple Podcasts
urls.description: ‎Show Healthcare Unfiltered, Ep Challenges and Bias against IMGs in America - Nov 14, 2022

urls.title: Challenges and Bias against IMGs in America
urls.description: Listen to this episode from Healthcare Unfiltered on Spotify. Chadi hosts a roundtable of five guests—four first-timers and one recurring guest—to discuss the challenges of international medical graduates (IMGs) in oncology and medicine in general in the US. Led by Ayesha Butt, MBBS, Department of Internal Medicine, Yale School of Medicine, the group discusses the findings of a recent nationwide survey, published in JCO Oncology Practice, that uncovered bias against IMGs in the hem/onc fellowship recruitment process. Additionally, they cover the struggles of acquiring a Visa to work in the US as well as to return to the US after a visit home, their personal stories experiencing bias, the need to “cast a wider net” when considering a pool of applicants for fellowship positions, and ways to overcome bias against IMGs, along with many other important discussion points. Read the article “Bias Against International Medical Graduates in the Hematology/Oncology Fellowship Recruitment Process:

urls.title: Bias Against International Medical Graduates in the Hematology/Oncology Fellowship Recruitment Process: Findings From a Nationwide Survey of Fellowship Program Directors
urls.description: IMGs are the most disadvantaged applicant group for hematology-oncology fellowships in the US, according to PDs.

urls.title: Annual Meeting Schedule-at-a-Glance
urls.description: All times listed reflect the Central time zone. Unless otherwise noted, all events will take place in person and on the virtual platform. Beginning at 9:00 a.m. Preview Day (virtual platform only) Preview Day is an opportunity to explore the annual meeting virtual platform and become familiar with its features and navigation. Participants will not have access to pre-recorded presentations that are subject to an embargo (i.e., oral abstract presentations and poster presentations). All Day Preview Day

I have never cried so much watching any film ever @Working_Title @NetflixUK

After 5 amazing years in Boston, I am excited to be going to NYC for Heme/Onc fellowship @MSKCancerCenter! 
Very thankful to mentors @DanaFarber @DrChoueiri @VanAllenLab @srviswanathan & @BrighamMedRes for all the support!
No more long distance w/ @ItsMeRomy!
#Match2022 https://t.co/OCDxiD6w6C
Hey #epitwitter - this feels like a long shot, but I'm searching for a #postdoc position in perinatal and/or substance use epi. I'd greatly appreciate any leads! https://t.co/MPrzpP2CsF

One of the hardest questions I face as a cancer doctor is: “Doc, how long do I have to live?”

The easy way out is to say I don’t know. But that doesn’t help.

I always give an estimate so patients can plan their lives. Often it is much better than what they fear #MedTwitter 

1/
Stamp of approval from many including @NarjustFlorezMD and @Florez_Lab ! @montypal will be an outstanding leader for @ASCO #VoteMonty https://t.co/lLKQFw9BwE

🚨@ASCO elections are currently ongoing🚨

Don’t forget to support @montypal, a visionary leader, who is committed to trainees and junior faculty. 
The future is bright!🌟 #VoteMonty 

🎯https://t.co/cWeBpiXsF9  #oncology https://t.co/i2sdLcLzTU

Given there will reporting delay for USMLE step 3 after December 31st, 2022, it puts IMGs (taking exams in Jan) at a disadvantage in ROL and ability to request for H1 visa. 

As a chair of @APPNA YPC, I wrote up to @TheUSMLE to delay this reporting period for 1-2 months. Lets see https://t.co/oWgU1ClQyE
https://t.co/I9gcoYYnXH

urls.title: Challenges and Bias against IMGs in America
urls.description: Listen to this episode from Healthcare Unfiltered on Spotify. Chadi hosts a roundtable of five guests—four first-timers and one recurring guest—to discuss the challenges of international medical graduates (IMGs) in oncology and medicine in general in the US. Led by Ayesha Butt, MBBS, Department of Internal Medicine, Yale School of Medicine, the group discusses the findings of a recent nationwide survey, published in JCO Oncology Practice, that uncovered bias against IMGs in the hem/onc fellowship recruitment process. Additionally, they cover the struggles of acquiring a Visa to work in the US as well as to return to the US after a visit home, their personal stories experiencing bias, the need to “cast a wider net” when considering a pool of applicants for fellowship positions, and ways to overcome bias against IMGs, along with many other important discussion points. Read the article “Bias Against International Medical Graduates in the Hematology/Oncology Fellowship Recruitment Process:

urls.title: Bias Against International Medical Graduates in the Hematology/Oncology Fellowship Recruitment Process: Findings From a Nationwide Survey of Fellowship Program Directors
urls.description: IMGs are the most disadvantaged applicant group for hematology-oncology fellowships in the US, according to PDs.

Next Tue on #HealthcareUnfiltered @DrChoueiri asks a provocative question: are IMGs discriminated against just BC they went to medical school abroad? @IMG_Oncologists 

Along W @DrAyeshaButt @ZiadBakouny @TarekHaykal1 @NazliDizman they bring up BIAS they all faced.
Don’t miss it. https://t.co/pFKZHv2LOT

Very important topic and a source of anxiety for all #IMGs, at least for me, which kept me from visiting my home country for 14 years now. I think @USCIS should really make it easier on those who elected to pursue higher education here and to serve this great nation. @ECFMG_IMG https://t.co/HzNJWz3DcH

I grew up in a poor country in a limited-resource family, & each time I go to 🇯🇴 & see a street seller, I think to myself I could have been easily one myself if it was not for studying hard, supportive family & good fortune. Always looks at positive side & count your blessings

Next week ⁦@DrAyeshaButt⁩ takes us through her survey data pub on bias, discrimination, & unfairness of how IMGs are treated in many programs in the US. Joined by ⁦@DrChoueiri⁩ ⁦@ZiadBakouny⁩ ⁦@TarekHaykal1⁩ ⁦@NazliDizman⁩ ⁦@IMG_Oncologists⁩ https://t.co/8pO7cCAdbk

For everyone who reached out asking me if I’m leaving twitter (total of zero people so far): 

The answer is no; I’m staying.

I’m staying on Twitter. Verified or not. 

I tweet on medicine, myeloma, cancer, healthcare policy, prescription drug costs, COVID, music, and more.

I would be remiss if I didn’t thank @MarkDSiegel1 @YaleIMed for allowing Nazli & I to continue to collaborate on the great body of research she has built at @cityofhope. She applies for fellowship this year - honestly, I’m losing more sleep over her match than I did my own! (2/2) https://t.co/rt4cuenLTf
